channel.title: Digital Brain on
channel.description: Recent content in Digital Brain on

item.title: $\subset$ and $\in$
item.description: $\subset$ and $\in$ The subset symbol $\subset$ is only used when referring to sets and not individual elements inside the sets.

item.title: Asymmetric Relations
item.description: Asymmetric Relations A relation $R$ is asymmetric if each pair of different elements does not have its inverse in the relation.

item.title: Bernoulli's Equation
item.description: Bernoulli’s Equation Bernoulli’s equation states that the properties of a fluid in one part of a system should be constant.

item.title: Bisection Method
item.description: Bisection Method This method looks to find the roots of a nonlinear equation. First we find the range $[a,b]$ over which we want to check for roots.

item.title: Canonical Base
item.description: Canonical Base Canonical base in $\mathbb{R}^2$: $$ \begin{align} e_i= \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 0 \end{bmatrix} && e_2= \begin{bmatrix} 0 \ 1 \end{bmatrix} && \longrightarrow && \begin{bmatrix} e_1 & e_2 \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \end{align} $$

item.title: Cardinality
item.description: Cardinality In set theory , the cardinality of set $A$ is the size of set $A$, $|A|$. #logic #setTheory

item.title: Cartesian Product
item.description: Cartesian Product Let $A$ and $B$ be two non empty sets . The Cartesian Product of these sets is the set of ordered pairs, which in turn, becomes a relation .

item.title: Chain Rule
item.description: Chain Rule $$ \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{dy}{du}\cdot \frac{du}{dx} $$ #math #calculus

item.title: Chain rule with multiple variables
item.description: Chain rule with multiple variables When applying the chain rule to functions with multiple variables, we must keep in mind that each of our internal functions can have several variables as well.

item.title: Compound Propositions
item.description: Compound Propositions Propositions formed by 2 or more simple propositions, connected with logical connectors , e.g, and, or, if.

item.title: Consistency of a SLE
item.description: Consistency of a SLE A system is consider consistent if it has a solution , if not, it’s considered inconsistent.

item.title: Coordinate Systems in 3 Dimensions
item.description: Coordinate Systems in 3 Dimensions Our 3 coordinates form 3 planes, $x, y, z$, which forms 8 quadrants. Points in this coordinate system have the form $P(x, y, z)$.

item.title: Coulomb's Law
item.description: Coulomb’s Law $$ F=\frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_0}\frac{|q_1q_2|}{r^2} $$ The force of attraction between two electrically charged particles is inversely proportional to the distance between them.

item.title: De Morgan's Law
item.description: De Morgan’s Law $$ \begin{rcases} (P \cup Q)^c = P^c \cap Q^c \ (P \cap Q)^c = P^c \cup Q^c \end{rcases} = \text{DeMorgan’s Law} $$ Union $\cup$ is can be considered as addition $+$, and intersection $\cap$ is multiplication $\times$.

item.title: Directional Derivative
item.description: Directional Derivative Partial derivatives show us rates of change in $x$ and $y$ for a given function $f(x, y)$.

item.title: Directional Derivatives in $\mathbb{R}^3$
item.description: Directional Derivatives in $\mathbb{R}^3$ The directional derivative in $f$ in the direction of $u$ is defined as: $$ D_uf(x_0,y_0,z_0)=f_x(x_0,y_0,z_0)u_1+f_y(x_0,y_0,z_0)u_2+f_z(x_0,y_0,z_0)u_3 $$ Let $f$ be a function of $3$ variables that is differentiable in $(x_0,y_0,z_0)$

item.title: Disjoint Sets
item.description: Disjoint Sets Sets $A$ and $B$ are disjoint sets if they have no elements in common, save for the empty set .

item.title: Electric Field
item.description: Electric Field Two particles $A$ and $B$ exercise forces against each other. We remove the smaller of the particles and replace it with a point $P$.

item.title: Equation of Continuity
item.description: Equation of Continuity When dealing with fluids, the equation of continuity states that the flow rate between one area of a system is the same as the flow rate at another part of the system.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description: Equivalence Relation An equivalence relation is a relation that is reflexive , symmetric , and transitive . It is the opposite of a partially ordered relation .

item.title: Evaluating Arguments
item.description: Evaluating Arguments Find the value of the following logical implication: $q, p\to q \models q$ Find the truth of each statement individually.

item.title: Experimental Uncertainty
item.description: Experimental Uncertainty Errors can appear from many different sources: Uncalibrated equipment Random errors Systematic errores Types of Uncertainty A: One must use a statistical procedure in order to find their numerical value.

item.title: Gradient Vector
item.description: Gradient Vector If $f$ is a function with two variable $x$ and $y$, the gradient of $f$ is the vectorial function $\triangledown f$, and is defined as: $$ \nabla f = \langle \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial y}{\partial y} \rangle $$ its main use is in finding the directional derivative of a function.

item.title: Graphing in MATLAB
item.description: Graphing in MATLAB Basic Functions plot(x,y) can accept a third argument, which changes the style of the line subplot(a,b,c) lets you have several plots at once, where a is the number of files, b is the number of columns, and c is the location of the current plot.

item.title: Identity Matrix
item.description: Identity Matrix The matrix $I_n$ is the matrix where all the numbers on the diagonal are $1$, starting from the upper left corner, and everything else is $0$.

item.title: Implication and Associates
item.description: Implication and Associates Let $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ be two defined predicates in a given universe. Let the quantified proposition be $\forall x [p(x) \to q(x)]$.

item.title: Inverse Relations
item.description: Inverse Relations Let $R$ be a relation . The inverse of $R$ is obtained by reversing each pair of ordered numbers inside the relation, and is denoted with $R^{-1}$.

item.title: Irreflexive Relations
item.description: Irreflexive Relations A relation $R$ is irreflexive if each element in the single set that created the relation is not paired with each itself.

item.title: Lagrange Multiplier
item.description: Lagrange Multiplier Given a multivariable function , and a constraint , we use a Lagrange Multiplier, $\lambda$, to find its minimums and maximums.

item.title: Lagrange's Theorem
item.description: Lagrange’s Theorem Lagrange’s theorem states that if a function$f$ has a extrema at $x_0,y_0$, given the restriction $g$, then there exists some value $\lambda$ such that $$ \nabla f(x_0,y_0)=\lambda \cdot \nabla g(x_0,y_0) $$

item.title: Laws of Logical Inference
item.description: Laws of Logical Inference In order to solve natural deduction problems, we use the following rules. #logic #formulas

item.title: Linear Equation Systems
item.description: Linear Equation Systems Linear equation systems A system of linear equations of size $m \times n$, has $m$ equations and $n$ variables, and can be abbreviated as SLE $m \times n$.

item.title: Linear Transformations
item.description: Linear Transformations The linear transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$, where $n$ and $m$ can be $2,3$, is a function that has the following properties:

item.title: Logic
item.description: Logic Logic is a formal science and philosophy that studies thought and its structures. It helps find the truth in statements , and the arguments between them.

item.title: Logical Connectors
item.description: Logical Connectors Words or symbols that help connect propositions , sets , etc. Symbol Connector Name $\neg$ no Negation $\wedge$ and Conjunction $\lor$ or Weak Disjunction $\oplus$ or Exclusive Disjunction $\to$ if Conditional $\leftrightarrow$ if and only if Equivalence #logic

item.title: Matrix
item.description: Matrix Matrices are rectangular arrangements of numbers. $$ A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{21} & \cdots & a_{1n} \ a_{21} & a_{31} & \cdots & a_{2n} \ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \ a_{m1} & a_{m2} & \cdots & a_{mn} \ \end{bmatrix} $$ The matrix $A$ is $m \times n$ big.

item.title: Matrix Addition
item.description: Matrix Addition In order to add two matrices they must be the same size, and each element of the matrices must be addable.

item.title: Matrix Multiplication
item.description: Matrix Multiplication When multiplying a matrix by a scalar, each element of the matrix is multiplied by the constant. $$ \begin{align} A= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \ 7 & 5\ \end{bmatrix} && 2A= \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 6 \ 14 & 10 \ \end{bmatrix} \end{align} $$

item.title: Matrix of a System
item.description: Matrix of a System Find the matrix of the system : $$ \begin{align} E_1:& 2x_1+3x_2-6x_3=9 \ E_2:& 4x_1+x_2+5x_3=13 \ E_1:& -2x_1+x_2+7x_3=2 \ \end{align} $$ $$ A= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 & -8 \ 4 & 1 & 5 \ -2 & 1 & 7 \ \end{bmatrix} $$ We take the coefficients of every term of our system of equations, and create a matrix with them.

item.title: Matrix Reflection
item.description: Matrix Reflection Reflection on $y$ axis $$ A= \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} $$ Reflection on $x$ axis $$ A= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} $$ #math #matrices #linearAlgebra

item.title: Maximum and Minimum with Constrains
item.description: Maximum and Minimum with Constraints When solving problems involving minimums and maximums , one can apply a constraint to the function.

item.title: Maximums and Minimums
item.description: Maximums and Minimums These points can be categorized as local or absolute. A local point is the highest/lower point for a specific area, and an absolute point is the highest/lowest point for the entire function.

item.title: Movement on a Curve
item.description: Movement on a Curve The magnitud of the speed function is defined as: $$ |v(t)|=\sqrt{(f'(t))^2+(g'(t))^2+(h'(t))^2} $$ And the length of the arch of the curve, from point $a$ to point $b$ is: $$ L=\int_a^b |v(t)|dt $$ #math #calculus #physics

item.title: Multivariable Functions
item.description: Multivariable Functions As opposed to functions with a single variable, multivariable functions can have several variables as inputs, returning a single output.

item.title: Natural Deduction
item.description: Natural Deduction Logic allows us to infer, through simple syntactical manipulation, new ideas from old ones. An argument is formed through a series of initial statements call Premises.

item.title: Null Set
item.description: Null Set In set theory , the Null Set $\emptyset$ contains nothing ${}$. #logic #setTheory

item.title: Order of [Logical Operations](compound-propositions.md)
item.description: Order of Logical Operations Negation Conjunction Disjunction Conditional Strong Disjunction Biconditional #logic

item.title: Parametric Curves
item.description: Parametric Curves A parametric curve is every curve that depends on some external variable for its creation. Examples can be curves dependent on time, temperature, lengths, etc.

item.title: Parametric Equations
item.description: Parametric Equations Physical phenomena, like the movement of a particle, can be described using a coordinate system $x,y,z$, and with a fourth parameter time.

item.title: Partial Derivatives
item.description: Partial Derivatives Multivariable functions require multivariable derivatives; for each variable in the function, a separate derivative is required.

item.title: Partial Derivatives in Higher Orders
item.description: Partial Derivatives in Higher Orders One can derive partial derivatives several times, either with respect with one variable or the other.

item.title: Partial Order Relation
item.description: Partial Order Relation A partial order relation is a relation that is irreflexive , asymmetric , and not transitive .

item.title: Predicates
item.description: Predicates A predicate is a statement that follows the following three rules: It contains 1 or more variables It’s not a proposition , but It becomes a proposition when its variables are substituted for concrete values.

item.title: Proof by Induction
item.description: Proof by Induction Example Prove using induction: $$ P(n)=1+2+3+\dots + n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2} $$ First, we prove its true for a base case $$ P(1)=\frac{1(2)}{2}=1 $$ Then we assume that $n=k$, $n$ is equal to some number $k$ $$ P(k)=1+2+3+\dots+k=\frac{k(k+1)}{2} $$ Then we check if this is still true for its successor $k+1$ $$ P(k+1)=1+2+3\dots+k+(k+1)=\frac{(k+1)((k+1)+1)}{2} $$ We see that what’s on in the middle part of the equation can be simplified as our case for $k$ $$ \frac{k(k+1)}{2}+(k+1)=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} $$ We continue to simplify terms to check if both sides are equal $$ \begin{align} (k+1)(\frac{k}{2}+1)&=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} \ (k+1)(\frac{k+2}{2})&=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} \ \frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2}&=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} \ \end{align} $$ Since this outcome is true, our initial statement is true.

item.title: Properties of Matrix Addition and Scalar Multiplication
item.description: Properties of Matrix Addition and Scalar Multiplication The following properties apply both to addition and multiplication : $A + B = B + A$: Commutativity $A + (B+C) = (A+B)+C$: Associativity $A(BC)=(AB)C$: Distributivity $A(B+C)=AB+AC$ $c(AB)=(cA)B=A(cB)$ #math #linearAlgebra #math

item.title: Properties of the Identity Matrix
item.description: Properties of the Identity Matrix If $A$ is a matrix of size $m \times n$, then the following statements are always true:

item.title: Propositions
item.description: Propositions In logic , propositions are statements which must be either true or false. There are 3 states a set of propositions can have:

item.title: Quadratic surfaces
item.description: Quadratic surfaces The equation of a quadratic surface is a second grade equation of the form $$Ax^2+By^2+Cz^2+Dxy+Exz+Fyz+Gx+Hy+Hz+J=0$$ There are 6 basic quadratic surfaces:

item.title: Quantifiers
item.description: Quantifiers $\forall$ is the universal quantifier $\exists$ is the existential quantifier Statements with expressions like: some, there exists, there are some, for all, every, etc, are existential quantifiers and universal quantifiers respectively.

item.title: R Programming Language
item.description: R Programming Language Programming language used for the analysis and visualization of data. Data Types Type Example Integer 1 Numeric 1.

item.title: Reflexive Relations
item.description: Reflexive Relations A relation $R$ is reflexive if each element in the single set that created the relation is paired with each itself.

item.title: Relations
item.description: Relations A relations is a set of ordered pairs created by taking elements from either a single set $A$, or two sets $A$, $B$.

item.title: Rotation Matrix
item.description: Rotation Matrix $$ A_\theta = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(\theta) & -\sin(\theta) \ \sin(\theta) & \cos(\theta) \ \end{bmatrix} $$ Multiplying this matrix with a vector in $\mathbb{R}^2$ will rotate it.

item.title: Set Complement
item.description: Set Complement The complement of set $A$ is every element in the universal set that’s not in $A$. It’s denoted with $A^c$, $\bar{A}$, or $A'$.

item.title: Set Difference
item.description: Set Difference Difference: The difference of sets $A$ and $B$ in the universal set $U$ is $$A - B = { x \in A | x \notin B }$$ #logic #setTheory

item.title: Set Intersection
item.description: Set Intersection Intersection: If $A$ and $B$ are sets in the universal set $U$, the intersection of these sets is defined as $$A \cap B = { x \in U | x \in A \land x \in B }$$ #logic #setTheory

item.title: Set theory
item.description: Set theory Sets are collections of things that are similar. Uppercase letters $A, B, C$ are used to denote the names of sets.

item.title: Set Union
item.description: Set Union Union: The union of sets $A$ and $B$ in the universal set $U$ is defined as $$A \cup B = { x \in U | x \in A \lor x \in B }$$ #logic #setTheory

item.title: SigFig Arithmetic
item.description: SigFig Arithmetic Rule: adding or subtracting numbers with decimals , the number of decimals of the answer is equal to the number with the least amount of decimal places.

item.title: Significant Figures
item.description: Significant Figures If there’s no decimal point, start counting from the right and skip zeroes. If there’s a decimal point, count from the left and skip zeros.

item.title: Singleton
item.description: Singleton In set theory , a singleton is a set containing a single element. #logic #setTheory

item.title: SLE Solution
item.description: SLE Solution The solution of a SLE is a vector that gives identities to all variables. Example: The vector $\vec{x} = \mycolv{2\1}$ solves the equations:

item.title: Spheres
item.description: Spheres Formal Definition A sphere is the group of all points in 3 dimensional space that are equidistant from some point $C(h,j,l)$.

item.title: Subsets
item.description: Subsets When dealing with sets , we can say that certain sets are subsets of other sets. $A$ is a subset of $B$ if and only if every element in $A$ is also an element of $B$.

item.title: Syllogism
item.description: Syllogism Argument that uses deductive reasoning to reach a conclusion. #logic

item.title: Symmetric Relations
item.description: Symmetric Relations A relation $R$ is symmetric if each pair of different elements has its inverse in the relation. $$ xRy \to yRx $$

item.title: Tangent Plane
item.description: Tangent Plane The infinitely small point on $z=f(x,y)$ is flat, and if we were to extend it infinitely across 3 dimensions , we’ll get a tangent plane to the original surface.

item.title: Total Differential
item.description: Total Differential Let $z=f(x,y)$ be a multivariable function and $dx$ and $dy$ infinitely small changes in $x$ and $y$ respectively.

item.title: Transitive Relations
item.description: Transitive Relations A relation $R$ is transitive if we can find a hypothetical syllogism within its elements. $$ (xRy)\land(yRz) \to xRz $$

item.title: Truth Tables
item.description: Truth Tables Truth tables evaluate the results of compound propositions by evaluating each simple proposition and finding their value .

item.title: Universal Set
item.description: Universal Set In set theory , the Universal Set $U$ contains all the considered elements. #logic #setTheory

item.title: Universe and Solution Set
item.description: Universe and Solution Set Let $P$ be a predicate . The universe $U$ is the set that entails all the possible values for the variables in $P$.

item.title: Vector
item.description: Vector A vector is a matrix in 2 dimensions, e.i, $1\times m$ or $n \times1$.

item.title: Volume Flow Rate
item.description: Volume Flow Rate Volume flow rate is the rate at which volume flows, and is measured in Volume per Time. $$ Q=Av $$

item.title: Zero Matrix
item.description: Zero Matrix The matrix $0_{mn}$ is the matrix of size $m \times n$ filled only with zeros. If using multiple digit numbers, a comma must be used between them.
